poem:
"Notes from a Super Tuesday"

In the hush of morning, democracy stirs,
a murmuration of opinion, inked onto ballots.
Trump, Biden, a world locked in a dance,
finding rhythm between a rock and hard place.
Gaza weeping, while Arlington casts votes in hope,
Each tick a whisper, each cross a prayer,
For a cease-fire, for a peace not yet written,
On the torn pages of humanity's tale.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Super Tuesday 2024 live: millions of voters head to polls across the US as Donald Trump appears likely to dominate Republican primary 6.58pm GMT Although many Democrats have sharply criticized Joe Biden’s handling of the war in Gaza, several primary voters who cast ballots in Arlington, Virginia, said they felt the president has done as much as he can to bring about a ceasefire. “I think he’s been between a rock and hard place,” said". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
